citations.narrative:
Several areas of the 6’ wooden perimeter fence have fallen into disrepair. There is an open gap in the fence that measure
approximately 18" x 24" at the bottom of the fence and one of similar size at a middle level as well. Multiple tops of the 6’
pickets have been damaged or broken off, causing the fence to be less than the required 6’ tall in several places. These
damaged areas of the perimeter fence could allow potential human or animal intruders to access the property and do not
provide for secondary containment if a regulated animal escapes its primary enclosure.
The regulations state that all outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter
fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 6 feet high for non-
dangerous animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects
the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having
contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in
the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between
animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence.
Correct by evaluating all areas of the perimeter fence and making the necessary repairs to ensure compliance with the
federal AWA. Correct by 21Nov2023.

Several areas around the animal primary enclosures contain excessive amounts of crates, tubs, feeders, rolls of wire,
cages and similar that are not in use. There is tall grass growing up in these areas as well as throughout much of the
facility. Not maintaining adequate housekeeping and landscaping measures provides places for vermin and pests to
accumulate, which can lead to disease-related issues or injury to the animals of the facility.
The regulations state that premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the
animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash
shall be placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
Correct by evaluating the amount of extra equipment being stored near the animal enclosures and addressing the
landscaping issues caused by the tall grass. Correct by 21Nov2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Several areas of the 6’ wooden perimeter fence have fallen into disrepair. There is an open gap in the fence that measure 
approximately 18" x 24" at the bottom of the fence and one of similar size at a middle level as well. Multiple tops of the 6’ 
pickets have been damaged or broken off, causing the fence to be less than the required 6’ tall in several places. These 
damaged areas of the perimeter fence could allow potential human or animal intruders to access the property and do not 
provide for secondary containment if a regulated animal escapes its primary enclosure.  
 
The regulations state that all outdoor housing facilities (i.e., facilities not entirely indoors) must be enclosed by a perimeter 
fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. Fences less than 6 feet high for non-
dangerous animals must be approved in writing by the Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects 
the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having 
contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a secondary containment system for the animals in 
the facility. It must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between 
animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence.  
 
Correct by evaluating all areas of the perimeter fence and making the necessary repairs to ensure compliance with the 
federal AWA. Correct by 21Nov2023. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
Several areas around the animal primary enclosures contain excessive amounts of crates, tubs, feeders, rolls of wire, 
cages and similar that are not in use. There is tall grass growing up in these areas as well as throughout much of the 
facility. Not maintaining adequate housekeeping and landscaping measures provides places for vermin and pests to 
accumulate, which can lead to disease-related issues or injury to the animals of the facility.  
 
The regulations state that premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the 
animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash 
shall be placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.

Correct by evaluating the amount of extra equipment being stored near the animal enclosures and addressing the 
landscaping issues caused by the tall grass. Correct by 21Nov2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
